DataElement.preferredName: Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization Image Probe Other Specify
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the free text field related to the other kind of Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization probe used that is captured in the image which will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization Image Probe
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping._Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic._General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will hybridize, a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.:Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.
Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Property.preferredDefinition: General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will hybridize, a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.

As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will hybridize, a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.
